s:subsection.s:paragraph: The jcanephora package implements a set of abstractions over OpenGL with the intention of providing an API that enforces program correctness statically. The OpenGL API is extremely error prone, but thankfully most of the problems can be alleviated with the simple application of static types. Where the Java type system is too weak to give static guarantees, dynamic checks are used to prevent silent failure.

Most functions in OpenGL return integers (type int). The glCreateShader() function, for example, returns an int regardless of whether the function is creating a fragment shader or a vertex shader. Obviously, returning a different type depending on whether a fragment shader or a vertex shader was requested would require a dependent type system. As Java clearly does not have dependent types, the jcanephora package provides a compileVertexShader() function that returns a value of type VertexShader and a compileFragmentShader() function that returns a value of type FragmentShader, eliminating any chance of confusing the two at compile-time. The package takes a similar approach to static safety throughout.

The jcanephora package also provides on-demand (re)compilation of GLSL shader programs via a simple Program API. The package is able to load programs from inside archives via jvvfs. The Program API also implements a simple abstraction over shading program parameters (attributes, uniforms) that makes it possible to query the names and types of parameters at run-time.

The package also provides functions to produce orthographic and perspective projection matrices, and an implementation of the ubiquitous lookAt() function for producing a view matrix that looks at a given point in space from a given location.

The jcanephora package attempts to provide abstractions that are as minimal as possible. It should be possible for any experienced OpenGL programmer to use the package without having to learn new concepts or fight a complicated class hierarchy. The idea is to provide static type safety in as simple a manner as possible.

As stated repeatedly, the jcanephora package strives for increased static and run-time type safety. This does, however, mean that there are new abstractions to learn. This section of the documentation attempts to describe how to use the API for those already familiar with OpenGL. It presents small programs written in C and then shows the jcanephora equivalent.

The following C program [vbo.c] demonstrates the creation of vertex buffer and index buffer objects in plain OpenGL. It creates buffers and then draws them to the screen using the fixed-function OpenGL pipeline.

Where the C version creates essentially untyped memory, the jcanephora version requires programmers to use explicit type descriptors for buffers. In order to write to the map, the programmer has to obtain access via typed cursors. Intuitively, if the array buffer is thought of as an array of records of a given type, the cursors can only point to specific fields in the records as they seek through the array. Note that in order to avoid introducing too much of the API at once and for direct comparison with the C version, the example code drops down to the fixed-function pipeline (via LWJGL) for rendering.

The following C program [texture-usage.c] demonstrates the creation and usage of textures. It loads a TIFF image using libTIFF, into a pixel buffer, copies the pixel buffer into a texture, binds the texture to the first texture unit, and displays it on a textured quad.

The jcanephora version reads an RGBA texture directly from a file. The image is converted to RGBA regardless of the format of the image. The jcanephora package requires the programmer to retrieve a list of the available texture units and then explicitly bind textures to the texture units for use. This eliminates an ugly class of bugs involving the programmer using more texture units than the implementation provides and then failing to check glGetError() (the bug may go completely unnoticed: who will notice that one texture out of thirty applied to an object is missing?).
Note that textures are always backed by pixel buffers in jcanephora and may therefore be mapped and then modified using typed cursors for trivial "streaming" textures.
